questions.neutral: Night's only just started, hasn't it?

hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Night’s young, sure. I’ll take it slow tonight.
Nothing better than relaxing after a long job.
I spend time exploring old utility spaces, that’s all.
Not as quiet as it used to be, what with all the recent chaos.
Still early. I go out walking under the city most nights.
Hobby of mine—urban exploration, in sealed maintenance spots.
Been trickier since everyone started poking into tunnels after the BCI fallout.
Had to dodge some squatters down there last week.
Makes you rethink what counts as peace and quiet.
Night just started, yeah. I’ve got a thing for urban exploring—tunnels, old server rooms.
Started years ago, crawling maintenance shafts no one’s mapped since the upgrades.
You’d be surprised how much of the city runs under our feet.
Since all that BCI mess, more folks wandering my usual spots.
Ran into a crew of ex-disappeareds last time, swapping stories.
Hobby’s taken a turn—less solitude, more politics.
Long night ahead, always a bit more to see underground.
I usually spend evenings exploring old data centers and disused corridors.
Picked it up back when the city still felt stable—these days, it’s like archaeology.
Blackout’s made things interesting: doors stuck, signals out, city shifting weirdly silent.
Bumped into some vanished folks down there sharing their stories—strangest crowd I’ve seen.
Used to be you’d find loose wires, now it’s rumor and revolution in every tunnel.
Makes me appreciate a glass after crawling in the dark.
Yeah, night’s young, but you can feel it’s heavier lately.
Used to be my therapy—wandering abandoned substations, mapping forgotten data centers for fun.
Got hooked working state contracts, then saw more of Stenograd underground than topside.
That freedom shifted when the BCI blacked out—locks failing, everyone stuck above ground or sneaking below.
Last week, I stumbled on a gathering of disappeared folks under North Sector—felt like history making itself.
They were mapping exits, tallying the city’s scars—no one trusts the system, not even the walls.
Funny thing, I fix things for a living, but even my hobby needs repairs now.
Miss the days you could taste the silence, not just other people’s fear.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still poking around tunnels, when I can.
Harder now, with all those people showing up lately.
Everyone gets twitchy after the leak and the blackouts.
Feels like someone’s always watching, even underground.
I stick to the quiet spots.
Been sneaking through old sectors, sure.
Not quite the same lately, too many new faces.
People started turning sealed spaces into meeting points after the data dump.
Council’s mess made my hobby crowded overnight.
I just keep my head down, don’t pick sides.
Let folks pass, do my own mapping.
Urban exploration? Still hanging on, barely.
Lost my usual spots after the BCI blackout and all those leaks.
Now half the city’s suddenly interested in basements and access hatches.
Ran into some vanished folks in an abandoned substation last week.
Used to be solitude, now it’s group therapy with strangers.
Guess after Halden and Lintz, everyone wants a place with no cameras.
Not sure if I like the company or not.
Urban exploring keeps me level, even now.
Funny how many disappeared folks are showing up down there these days.
Since the records leaked, everyone’s hunting for safe corners or old systems.
Had a session last Friday—figured I’d drink in peace, found a crowd sharing war stories.
Feels personal, watching people reclaim the tunnels after what BCI did.
My go-to sector’s practically a support group now.
It’s odd—places built for data now fill up with old grievances.
Makes you wonder what else Halden buried.
Urban exploration’s still my fix, but it’s changed fast.
Whole network’s crawling with returned ghosts—people BCI wiped clean, now hunting for proof.
After Oksana’s archive went public, folks started mapping out every forgotten space they could find.
Friday, I found my favorite coolant manifold crowded with people I only knew from system logs.
They treat every tunnel like a border crossing, sharing stories they were never meant to tell.
Some ask me about Directorate tricks for dodging sensors—old habits, you know.
Maybe I miss the quiet, but now it feels like resistance lives underground.
The Council’s up top fighting about inquiries, but down below, folks are actually planning.
If you’d told me my hobby would turn political, I’d’ve called you drunk.
